habitat_description:
The range of the Brazos river watersnake is restricted to the Brazos River drainage region of north-central Texas (Dorcas and Mendelson 1991; Scott et al. 1989). This species is known to burrow in or using soil, fallen logs, and leaf litter (Natureserve.org).

Habitats occupied by this species include creeks, high gradient streams and rivers, shallow water pools and riffles. It also occupies riparian zones characterized by bare rock, talus, and scree. Preferred habitats include fast-flowing rocky streams with reduced vegetation on its margins (Werler and Dixon 2000), also found along shore lines of impoundments (Ernst and Ernst 2003). Cover is primarily obtained by using rocks and vegetation nearby water bodies (Conant 1975; Tennant 1984). Scott et al. (1989) described juveniles of this species to be likely to use large, flat rocks on unshaded portions of riparian zones for basking and hiding, rocky shallows for foraging. Adults were reported to prefer rocky riffles and a wider range of habitats in shallow water pools and lakes than juveniles.

This species is found in water bodies with sparse vegetation, but still depend on riparian cover for hiding, foraging, and basking opportunities.
